title: Sri Lanka looking at relaxing forced selling rules: CSE Chairman
body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is looking at relaxing forced sell rules, Colombo Stock Exchange Chairman Dumith Fernando said following a widely expected economic meltdown and default after two years of money printing.
“We are in the process of relaxing some measures with regard to forced selling,” Fernando told reporters after the regulator ordered a five day closure of the market following steep losses.
On April 12 the government said it is suspending foreign debt payment, shortly after hiking policy rates to 14.5 percent from 7.5 percent.
Fernando defended the decision to close saying it was to protect investors and give more time for clarity and for information to be digested.
“There should be information available for decision making,” he said.
When stock prices fall, margin providers ask stockholder who had bought on credit to sell, in a margin call, which tends to accelerate a downturn.
There is about 14 billion rupees of broker credit and banks have given more margin credit.

Sri Lanka’s stock market was driven almost entirely by domestic buyers and low interest rates enforced by the central bank to boost growth (output gap targeting) under flexible inflation targeting, despite having a pegged exchange.
When interest rates are artificially kept down by a central by printing money (inflating reserve money) the present value of long term assets go up, and there is usually mal-investment.
As foreign reserves dwindled due to money printing, many foreign investors selling out steadily.

Before unusual money printing began around the beginning of 2020, Sri Lanka had experienced two currency crisis in quick succession under stop-go policies (brakes are hit early after money is printed for output gap targeting) and both economic growth and stock prices were depressed.  (Colombo/Apr18/2022)
